Step Finance reports ~$30M SOL treasury breach

@StepFinance_ confirmed a compromise of multiple treasury and fee wallets, with 261,854 $SOL unstaked and transferred to new addresses, according to onchain data.

The breach triggered a sharp selloff in the $STEP token, which fell roughly 80% within 24 hours. The team said user funds were not affected and that it is working with cybersecurity firms to investigate the incident.

This is the third Solana DeFi treasury breach reported in January, highlighting continued security risks around protocol owned funds despite the use of multi signature wallets.

INTRODUCTION Converting Peruvian Soles (PEN) to US Dollars (USD) in 2026 depends largely on how the exchange is made. Cash withdrawals, card payments, and online transfers all apply different fees and exchange rate markups, which can noticeably reduce the final amount received, especially for larger transactions.  Why do PEN/USD rates differ by method? Banks, card issuers, ATM operators, and transfer platforms each use their own pricing models. These include FX markups, fixed service fees, foreign transaction charges, and Dynamic Currency Conversion (DCC), which often increases costs when accepted.  How much can rates vary? â€¢ Online transfers and crypto platforms: ~0.5â€“1.5% above mid-market â€¢ Fee-free card payments: ~1â€“2% â€¢ Cards with FX fees: ~2â€“4% â€¢ ATM withdrawals: ~3â€“8% â€¢ Airport exchanges: 10% or more As of January 2026, the mid-market rate is about 1 PEN = 0.298 USD, though actual payouts are usually lower after fees.  Why are ATMs more expensive? ATM withdrawals combine bank FX fees, operator charges, and hidden rate markups. Accepting DCC can add an extra 3â€“8% to the cost.   Which option is most efficient? Fintech and crypto platforms like Wise, Revolut, and Bitget typically offer the best rates. Cards are convenient but vary by issuer, while cash and airport exchanges are the least cost-effective.  Conclusion Online transfers consistently provide the best value for PEN/USD conversions. Cards sit in the middle, while ATMs and airport desks remain the most expensive. Choosing the right method can significantly reduce long-term conversion losses.   FAQ  â€¢ Current rate: ~0.298 USD per PEN â€¢ Bank rates worse than Google? Fees + markups â€¢ Pay in PEN or USD? The exchange rate you receive depends heavily on the platform or service you use.  What is the PEN to USD exchange rate?  The Peruvian $SOL   typically trades around 0.26â€“0.30 USD per 1 PEN, but the exact rate changes daily based on global FX markets.  Most users check the mid-market rate first, then compare what providers actually offer after fees and spreads.  Why does the exchange method matter?  Different services apply different costs:  Some charge hidden spreads  Others charge fixed conversion fees  Which Platforms Can You Use to Convert PEN to USD? Bitget  Bitget is mainly known as a crypto exchange, but users often convert local fiat into USD value through stablecoins like USDT. This can be useful for faster settlement compared to traditional methods.  Binance  Binance supports a wide range of fiat channels and P2P markets globally. In many regions, users exchange local currency into USD stablecoins, then withdraw or trade with deep liquidity.  Western Union  Western Union remains widely used for cash-based conversions and remittances, though rates are usually less competitive than digital platforms.  Local Banks and Exchange Houses  Peruvian banks and casas de cambio offer direct cash exchange, but rates vary widely and often include higher markups.  Conclusion  Exchanging Peruvian Sol to USD in 2026 can be done through banks, fintech apps, or crypto platforms. Services like Wise offer direct FX conversion, while exchanges like Bitget and Binance provide alternative routes through stablecoins and P2P markets.  FAQ  Do exchange rates differ across platforms?
